analytic.title: Rational BV-algebra in String Topology

biblStruct.note: To Micheline Vigué-Poirrier on her 60th birthday

abstract.p: Let M be a 1-connected closed manifold and LM be the space of free loops on M .

body.p: Various isomorphisms of graded algebras have been constructed. The first one has been constructed by Cohen and Jones for any field of coefficients in terms of spectra, [5]. Then Merkulov did it for for real coefficients [23], [13] using iterated integrals. Finally for rational coefficients, M. Vigué and the two authors have constructed another isomorphism, [12], using the chain coalgebra of the Quillen minimal model of M . Although HH * (A; A) does not have, for any differential graded algebra A, a natural structure of BV-algebra extending the canonical Gerstenhaber algebra, a second natural question is:

Does there exist on HH * (C * (M ); C * (M )) a structure of BV-algebra extending the structure of Gerstenhaber algebra and an isomorphism of BV-algebras between IH * (LM ) and HH * (C * (M ); C * (M ))?
The main result of this paper furnishes a positive answer to Question 2 and thus to Question 1 when the field of coefficients is assumed of characteristic zero.

If M is 1-connected and the field of coefficients has characteristic zero then there exists a BV-structure on HH * (C * (M ); C * (M )) and an isomophism of BV-algebras IH * (LM ) ∼ = HH * (C * (M ); C * (M )).

BV-algebra structures on the Hochschild cohomology HH * (A; A) have been constructed by different authors under some conditions on A. First of all, Tradler and Zeinalian did it when A is the dual of an A ∞ -coalgebra with ∞-duality (rational coefficients), [29]. This is in particular the case when A = C * (M ), [28]. In [21] Menichi constructed also a BV-structure in the case when A is a symmetric algebra (any coefficients). Let mention also the construction due to Vaintrob of a BV-structure on HH * (A; A) when A is the group ring with rational coefficients of the fundamental group of an aspherical manifold [30]. Vaintrob gives also an isomorphism of BV-algebras between IH(LM ) and HH * (A; A). This is coherent with our Theorem 1 because in this case C * (ΩM ) is quasi-isomorphic to A and using [9], we have isomorphisms of Gerstenhaber algebras

Extending Theorem 1 to finite fields of coefficients would be difficult. For instance Menichi proved in [22] that the algebras IH(LS 2 ) and HH * (H * (S 2 ); H * (S 2 )) are isomorphic as Gerstenhaber algebras but not as BV-algebras for Z/2-coefficients.

In this paper we work over a field of characteristic zero. We use rational homotopy and we refer to [7] for rational models. We only recall that a morphism in some category of complexes is a quasi-isomorphism if it induces an isomorphism in homology. Two objects are quasi-isomorphic if they are related by a finite sequence of quasi-isomorphisms. Now by a recent result of Lambrechts and Stanley, [19] there is a commutative differential graded algebra A satisfying: 1. A is quasi-isomorphic to the differential graded algebra C * (M ). 2. A is connected, finite dimensional and satisfies Poincaré duality in dimension m. This means there exists a A-linear isomorphism θ : A → A ∨ of degree −m which commutes with the differentials.

We call A a Poincaré duality model for M . This model can replace C * (M ) in the Hochschild cohomology because there is an isomorphism of Gerstenhaber algebra between HH * (C * (M ); C * (M )) and HH * (A; A) ([9]).
Denote by µ the multiplication of A. We define the linear map µ A : A → A ⊗ A by the commutative diagram

figure.trash: ( * ) A ∨ µ ∨ / / (A ⊗ A) ∨ = A ∨ ⊗ A ∨ A µ A / / θ O O A ⊗ A θ⊗θ O O

body.p: By definition µ A is a degree m homomorphism of A-bimodules which commutes with the differentials. Let C * (A; A) := (A ⊗ T (s ¯ A), ∂) be the Hochschild complex of A with coefficients in A. Here T (s ¯ A) denotes the free coalgebra generated by the graded vector space s ¯ A with ¯ A = {A i } i≥1 and (s ¯ A) i = A i+1 . We prove:

figure.trash: Proposition 1. 1. The complex C * (A; A) is quasi-isomorphic to C * (LM ). 2. If φ : T (s ¯ A) → T (s ¯ A) ⊗ T (s ¯ A) denotes the coproduct of T (s ¯ A) then the composition Φ : A⊗T (s ¯ A) id⊗φ → A⊗T (s ¯ A)⊗T (s ¯ A) ∼ = A⊗ A ⊗2 (A⊗T (s ¯ A)) ⊗2 µ A ⊗id → A ⊗2 ⊗ A ⊗2 (A⊗T (s ¯ A)) ⊗2

body.p: is a linear map of degree m which commutes with the differentials. 3. The isomorphism HH * (A; A) * +m ∼ = H * (LM ) transfers the map induced by Φ to the dual to the Chas-Sullivan product.

figure.trash: 4. The duality isomorphism HH * (A; A) ∨ ∼ = HH * (A; A ∨ ) (θ)
figure.figDesc: ∼ = HH * −m (A; A) transfers the map induced by Φ on HH * (A; A) to the Gerstenhaber product on HH * (A; A). Denote by ∆ : IH * (LM ) → IH * +1 (LM ) and ∆ ′ : IH * (LM ) → IH * −1 (LM ) the morphisms induced by the canonical action of S 1 on LM . As proved by Chas and Sullivan the morphism ∆ together with the loop product equip the loop space homology H * (M ) with a a BV-structure. We prove:
figure.head: Proposition 2.

figure.figDesc: The Connes' boundary B : C * (A; A) → C * −1 (A; A) induces a map in homology corresponding to the operator ∆ ′ via the isomorphism HH * (A; A) ∼ = H * (LM ).

body.p: On the other hand, the duality isomorphism HH * (

figure.trash: A; A) ∨ ∼ = HH * (A; A ∨ ) (θ) ∼ = HH * (A; A) transfers the linear dual of the Connes'operator B to an operator on HH * (A; A) that gives to the Hochschild cohomology a BV-structure extending the Gerstenhaber algebra structure ([21]

figure.figDesc: ) and HH * (A; A) ∼ = HH * (C * (M ); C * (M )) as Gerstenhaber algebras [9]

body.p: . This fact combined with Proposition 1 and 2 gives Theorem 1.

Since the field of coefficients is of characteristic zero, the homology of LM admits a Hodge decomposition, IH * (LM ) = ⊕ r≥0 IH [r] * (LM ), [15], [20, Theorem 4.5.10]. We prove that this decomposition behaves well with respect to the loop product • and the BVoperator ∆ defined by Chas-Sullivan.

figure.head: Theorem 2.
figure.figDesc: With the above notations, we have • IH [r] * (LM ) ⊗ IH [s]

body.p: By definition IH [0] * (LM ) is the image of H * −m (M ) by the homomorphism induced in homology by the canonical section M → LM . It has been proved in [10] that if autM denotes the monoid of (unbased) self-equivalences of M then there exist an isomorphism of graded algebras IH [1] * (LM ) ∼ = H * −m (M ) ⊗ π * (ΩautM ). For any r ≥ 0, a description of IH [r] * (LM ) can be obtained, using a Lie model (L, d) of M , as proved in the last result.

figure.head: Proposition 3.
figure.figDesc: The graded vector space IH [r]

body.p: * (LM ) is isomorphic to Tor U L (Ik, Γ r (L)) where Γ r (L) is the sub U L-module of U L for the adjoint representation that is the image of r L by the classical Poincaré-Birkoff-Witt isomorphism of coalgebras ∧L → U L.

The text is organized as follows. Notation and definitions are made precise in sections 2 and 3. Proposition 1 is proved in Sections 4, Proposition 2 is proved in section 5. Theorem 2 and Proposition 3 are proved in the last section.

figure.trash: 2 Hochschild homology and cohomology 2.1 Bar construction Let A be a differential graded augmented cochain algebra and let P (respectively N ) be a differential graded right (respectively left) A-module, A = {A i } i≥0 P = {P j } j∈Z , N = {N j } j∈Z and ¯ A = ker(ε : A → Ik). The two-sided (normalized) bar construction, IB(P ; A; N ) = P ⊗ T (s ¯ A) ⊗ N , IB k (P ; A; N ) = P ⊗ T k (s ¯ A) ⊗ N , is the cochain complex defined as follows: For k ≥ 1, a generic element p[a 1 |a 2 |...|a k ]n in IB k (P ; A; N ) has (upper) degree |p| + |n| + k i=1 (|sa i |) . If k = 0, we write p[ ]n = p ⊗ 1 ⊗ n ∈ P ⊗ T 0 (s ¯ A) ⊗ N . The differential d = d 0 + d 1 is defined by: IB k (P ; A; N ) l d 0 → IB k (P ; A; N ) l+1 , IB k (P ; A; N ) l d 1 → IB k−1 (P ; A; N ) l+1 d 0 (p[a 1 |a 2 |...|a k ]n) = d(p)[a 1 |a 2 |...|a k ]n − k i=1 (−1) ǫ i p[a 1 |a 2 |...|d(a i )|...|a k ]n +(−1) ǫ k+1 p[a 1 |a 2 |...|a k ]d(n) d 1 (p[a 1 |a 2 |...|a k ]n) = (−1) |p| pa 1 [a 2 |...|a k ]n + k i=2

body.p: (−1) ǫ i p[a 1 |a 2 |...|a i−1 a i |...|a k ]n −(−1) ǫ k p[a 1 |a 2 |...|a k−1 ]a k n Here ǫ i = |p| + j<i (|sa j |).
In particular, considering Ik as a trivial A-bimodule we obtain the complex IBA = IB(Ik; A; Ik) which is a differential graded coalgebra whose comultiplication is defined by φ([a 1

Recall that a differential A-module N is called semifree if N is the union of an increasing sequence of sub-modules N (i), i ≥ 0, such that each N (i)/N (i − 1) is an R-free module on a basis of cycles ([7]). Then,
The canonical map ϕ : B(A; A; A) → A defined by ϕ[ ] = 1 and ϕ([a 1 | · · · |a k ]) = 0 if k > 0, is a semifree resolution of A as an A-bimodule.

div.head: Hochschild complexes
div.p: Let us denote by A e = A ⊗ A op the envelopping algebra of A. If P is a differential graded (right) A-bimodule then the cochain complex

figure.trash: C * (P ; A) := (P ⊗ T (s ¯ A), ∂) def ∼ = P ⊗ A e IB(A; A; A)
figure.figDesc: is called the Hochschild chain complex of A with coefficients in P . Its homology is called the Hochschild homology of A with coefficients in P and is denoted by HH * (A; P ). When we consider C * (A; A) as well as HH * (A; A), A is supposed equipped with its canonical bimodule structure.

div.p: If N is a (left) differential graded A-bimodule then the cochain complex

figure.trash: C * (A; N ) := (Hom(T (s ¯ A), N ), δ) def ∼ = Hom A e (IB(A; A; A), N ) is
figure.figDesc: called the Hochschild cochain complex of A with coefficients in the differential graded A-bimodule N . Its cohomology is called the Hochschild cohomology of A with coefficients in N and is denoted by HH * (A; N ). When we consider C * (A; A) as well as HH * (A; A), A is supposed equipped with its canonical bimodule structure.

div.p: Let us denote by V ∨ the graded dual of the graded vector space V = {V i } i∈Z , i.e.

figure.trash: V ∨ = {V ∨ i } i∈Z with V ∨ i := Hom(V i , Ik) . The canonical isomorphism Hom(A ⊗ A e IB(A; A; A), Ik) → Hom A e (IB(A; A; A), A
figure.figDesc: ∨ ) induces the isomorphism of complexes C * (A; A) ∨ → C * (A; A ∨ ). 2.3 The Gerstenhaber algebra on HH * (A; A) A Gerstenhaber algebra is a commutative graded algebra H = {H i } i∈Z with a bracket H i ⊗ H j → H i+j−1 , x ⊗ y → {x, y} such that for a, a ′ , a ′′ ∈ H: (a) {a, a ′ } = (−1) (|a|−1)(|a ′ |−1) {a ′ , a} (b) {a, {a ′ , a ′′ }} = {{a, a ′ }, a ′′ } + (−1) (|a|−1)(|a ′ |−1) {a ′ , {a, a ′′ }}. For instance the Hochschild cohomology HH * (A; A) is a Gerstenhaber algebra [14]
The bracket can be defined by identifying C * (A; A) with a differential graded Lie algebra of coderivations ([24]

BV-algebras and differential graded Poincaré duality algebras. A Batalin-Vilkovisky algebra (BV-algebra for short) is a commutative graded algebra, H together with a linear map (called a BV-operator) ∆ : H k → H k−1 such that (1) ∆ • ∆ = 0 (2) H is a Gerstenhaber algebra with the bracket defined by

div.p: A differential graded Poincaré algebra (A, d) is a finite dimensional commutative differential graded algebra together with an isomorphism of differential A-modules, θ : A → A ∨ . When (A, d) is a differential graded Poincaré algebra, then HH * (A; A) is a BV-algebra [21]

figure.figDesc: . The BV-operator ∆ is obtained from the Connes' boundary on C * (A; A): B : C n (A; A) → C n+1 (A; A) ,

⊗ [a i |...|a n |a 0 |a 1 |...|a i−1 ] si |a 0 | > 0 where ¯ ǫ i = (|sa 0 | + |sa 1 | + ... + |sa i−1 |)(|sa i | + ... + |sa n |) . It is well known that B 2 = 0 and B • ∂ + ∂ • B = 0 . The operator ∆ is the image of B ∨ by the duality isomorphism (HH * +m (A; A)) ∨ ∼ = HH * +m (A; A ∨ )
figure.trash: (θ) ∼ = HH * (A; A). 3 The

figure.figDesc: Sullivan algebra structure on IH * (LM) and its dual

div.p: We assume in this section and in the following ones that Ik is a field of characteristic zero. Denote by p 0 : LM → M the evaluation map at the base point, and recall that the space LM can be replaced by a smooth manifold ([4], [25]) so that p 0 is a smooth locally trivial fibre bundle ([1], [25]).

figure.head: The loop product
figure.figDesc: • : H * (LM ) ⊗2 → H * −m (LM ) , x ⊗ y → x • y

div.p: was first defined by M. Chas and D. Sullivan, [3]

figure.figDesc: , by using " transversal geometric chains " . With the loop product, IH * (LM ) := H * +m (LM ) is a commutative graded algebra. It is convenient for our purpose to introduce the dual of the loop product H * (LM ) → H * +m (LM ×2 ). Consider the commutative diagram
figure.trash: (1) LM ×2 i ←− LM × M LM Comp −→ LM p ×2 0 ↓ p 0 ↓ ↓ p 0 M ×2 ∆ ←− M = M where -Comp denotes

div.p: composition of free loops, -the left hand square is a pullback diagram of locally trivial fibrations, -i is the embedding of the manifold of composable loops into the product LM × LM .
The embeddings ∆ and i have both codimension m. Thus, using the Thom-Pontryagin construction we obtain the Gysin maps:

figure.trash: ∆ ! : H k (M ) → H k+m (M ×2 ) , i ! : H k (LM × M LM ) → H k+m (LM ×2 ) . Thus diagram (1) yields the following diagram: (2) H k+m (LM ×2 ) i ! ←− H k (LM × M LM ) H k (Comp) ←− H k (LM ) H * (p 0 ) ⊗2 ↑ H * (p 0 ) ↑ ↑ H * (p 0 ) H k+m (M ×2 ) ∆ ! ←− H k (M ) = H k (M ) Following ([26]

div.p: , [6]), the dual of the loop product is defined by composition of maps on the upper line :

figure.trash: i ! • H * (Comp) : H * (LM ) → H * +m (LM ×2 ) . 4 A
figure.figDesc: Hochschild chain model for the dual of the loop product The composition of free loops Comp : LM × M LM → LM is obtained by pullback from the composition of paths Comp ′ : M I × M M I → M I in the following commutative diagram.
figure.trash: (Comp) LM × M LM j / / ev 0 Comp x x q q q q q q q q q q q M I × M M I ev 0 ,ev 1 ,ev 0 Comp' x x r r r r r r r r r r r LM j / / ev 0 =p 0 M I (ev 0 ,ev 1 ) M (id×∆)@BULLET∆ / / q q

div.p: q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q q

figure.trash: M ×3 pr 13 x x q q q q q q q q q q M ∆ / / M ×2

div.p: Here ∆ denotes the diagonal embedding, j the obvious inclusions, ev t denotes the evaluation maps at t, and pr 13 the map defined by pr 13 (a, b, c) = (a, c). Let (A, d) be a commutative differential graded algebra quasi-isomorphic to the differential graded algebra C * (M ). A cochain model of the right hand square in diagram (Comp) is given by the diagram

figure.trash: ( †) IB(A; A; A) Ψ / / IB(A; A; A) ⊗ A IB(A; A; A) A ⊗2 O O ψ / / A ⊗3 O O where Ψ and ψ denote the homorphism of cochain complexes defined by Ψ(a ⊗ [a 1 |...|a k ] ⊗ a ′ ) = k i=0 a ⊗ [a 1 |...|a i ] ⊗ 1 ⊗ [a i+1 |...|a k ] ⊗ a ′ , and ψ(a ⊗ a ′ ) = a ⊗ 1 ⊗ a ′ .

div.p: The multiplication µ : A ⊗ A → A makes A a A-bimodule, and is a model for the diagonal ∆. We consider now the diagram obtained by tensoring diagram ( †) by A over A ⊗2 .

figure.trash: ( ‡) A ⊗ A ⊗2 IB(A, A, A) id⊗Ψ / / A ⊗ A ⊗2 IB(A; A; A) ⊗ A IB(A; A; A) A ⊗ A ⊗2 A ⊗2 O O id⊗ψ / / A ⊗ A ⊗2 A ⊗3 O O

div.p: Since IB(A; A; A) is a semifree model of A as A-bimodule, we deduce from [7] that this diagram is a cochain model of the left hand square. Thus we have proved:

figure.head: Lemma 2.
figure.figDesc: The cochain complex C * (A; A) is a cochain model of LM , and we have an isomorphism of graded vector spaces HH * (A, A) ∼ = H * (LM ) .

div.p: Moreover, if φ denotes the the coproduct of the coalgebra T (s ¯ A) then the composition Φ,

figure.trash: C * (A; A) ∼ = A ⊗ T (s ¯ A) id⊗φ → A ⊗ T (s ¯ A) ⊗ T (s ¯ A) = C * (A; A) ⊗ A C * (A; A) ,
figure.head: is model of the composition of free loops.
figure.figDesc: Let (A, d) be a differential graded Poincaré duality model of M , as defined in the Introduction. Recall now that the Gysin map ∆ ! of the diagonal embedding ∆ : M → M × M is the Poincaré dual of the homomorphism H * (∆). This means that the following diagram is commutative
Thus the linear map of degree µ A = A → A ⊗ A defined in the introduction (Diagram ( * )) is a cochain model for ∆ ! .

div.p: Remark, [24], that we can choose the pullback of a tubular neighborhood of the diagonal embedding ∆ as a tubular neighborhood of the embedding i : LM × L M → LM × LM . We deduce that

figure.head: Lemma 3.
figure.figDesc: The linear map of degree m C * (A; A) ⊗ A C * (A, A) ∼ = A ⊗ A ⊗2 C * (A; A)
figure.trash: ⊗2 µ A ⊗id → C * (A; A) ⊗2

div.p: commutes with the differential and induces i ! in homology.
The next Lemma follows from standard computation. In combination with Lemma 2 and 3, it gives the proof of Proposition 1 of the Introduction.

figure.head: Lemma 4.
figure.figDesc: The duality isomorphism (HH * +m (A; A)) ∨ ∼ = HH * +m (A; A ∨ )

div.head: (θ)
div.p: ∼ = HH * (A; A) transfers the map induced by Φ on HH * (A; A) to the Gerstenhaber product on HH * (A; A).

Remark. By putting F p := A ⊗ T (s ¯ A) ≤p , for p ≥ 0, we define a filtration A ⊗ T (s ¯ A) ⊃ ... ⊃ F p ⊃ F p−1 ⊃ ... ⊃ A = F 0 such that ∂F p ⊂ F p and Φ(F p ) ⊂ ⊕ k+ℓ=p F k ⊗ F ℓ . The resulting spectral sequence

figure.trash: E p,q 2 = H q (M ) ⊗ H p (ΩM ) =⇒ H p+q (LM )
figure.figDesc: is the multiplicative Serre spectral sequence for the fibration p 0 : LM → M . It dualizes into a spectral sequence of algebras H q+m (M ) ⊗ H p (ΩM ) =⇒ IH p+q (LM ) .

div.p: We recover in this way over Q the spectral sequence defined previously by Cohen, Jones and Yan [6]

div.head: The

figure.head: canonical circle action on LM
figure.figDesc: Let ρ : S 1 × LM → LM be the canonical action of the circle on the space LM . The action ρ induces an operator ∆ : IH * (LM ) → IH * +1 (LM ). The loop product together with ∆ gives to IH * (LM ) a BV-structure [3]
Denote by M M = ( V, d) a (non necessary minimal) Sullivan model for M [8, §-12]

We put sV = ¯ V and denote by S the derivation of V ⊗ ¯ V defined by S(v) = ¯ v and S(¯ v) = 0 for v ∈ V and ¯ v ∈ ¯ V . Then a Sullivan model for LM is given by the commutative differential graded algebra ( V ⊗ ¯ V , ¯ d) where ¯ d(¯ v) = −S(dv) [27]

div.p: . Moreover in [2] Burghelea and Vigué prove that a Sullivan model of the action ρ : S 1 × LM → LM is given by M ρ : (

figure.figDesc: In particular the map induced in cohomology by the action of S 1 on LM is given by the derivation S : H * ( V ⊗ ¯ V ) → H * −1 ( V ⊗ ¯ V ). Denote now by B the Connes' boundary on C * (M M ; M M )) = V ⊗ T (s V ). Vigué proved the following Lemma in [31, Theorem 2.4]

figure.head: Lemma 5.
figure.figDesc: The morphism f : C * (M M ; M M ) → (M M ⊗ ¯ V ) defined by f (a ⊗ [a 1 | · · · |a n ]) = 1 n! aS(a 1 ) · · · S(a n )

div.p: is a quasi-isomorphism of complexes and f • B = S • f .

figure.trash: This, combined with lemma 4, implies directly Proposition 2 of the Introduction. 6 The Hodge decomposition
figure.figDesc: With the notation of the previous sections, let ( V ⊗ ¯ V , ¯ d) be a Sullivan model for LM . Denote by G p = V ⊗ p ¯ V the subvector space generated by the words of length p in ¯ V . The differential ¯ d satisfies ¯ d(G p ) ⊂ G p . Thus we put H n [p] (LM ) := H n (G p ) .

div.p: This decomposition has been considered by many authors (see for instance [20], [32]). It induces by duality a Hodge decomposition on H * (LM ). We are now ready to prove

figure.head: Theorem 2 of the Introduction.
figure.figDesc: Proof of Theorem 2. Recall that the differential d in C * (M M ; M M ) decomposes into d = d 0 + d 1 with d 0 (M M ⊗ T p (s∧V )) ⊂ M M ⊗ T p (s∧V ), and d 1 (M M ⊗ T p (s∧V )) ⊂ M M ⊗ T p−1 (s∧V ). We consider the quasi-isomorphism f : C * (M M ; M M ) → (M M ⊗ ¯ V , ¯ d) defined in

div.p: If we apply Lemma 5, when d = 0 in ∧V , we deduce that Ker f is d 1 -acyclic.

figure.trash: Denote K (p) = Ker f ∩ M M ⊗ T p (s∧V ) . Then Lemma 6. 1. If ω ∈ K (p) ∩ Ker ∂ then there exists ω ′ ∈ ⊕ r≥p+1 K (r) such that ∂ω ′ = ω. 2. f induces a surjective map M M ⊗ T ≥p (s∧V ) ∩ Ker ∂ ։ (M M ⊗ p sV ) ∩ Ker ¯ d .

div.p: Proof. If ω ∈ K (p) ∩ Ker ∂ then ω = ∂(u + v) with u ∈ K (p) and v ∈ K (≥p+1) . Since ∂ 1 u = 0 we have u = ∂β 1 some β ∈ K (p+1) and thus ω − dβ 1 ∈ K (≥p+1) . An induction on n ≥ 1 we prove that there exists β n ∈ K (p+n) such that ω − dβ n ∈ K (p+n) . Since V is

div.head: 1-connected
div.p: M M ⊗ T p+n (s∧V ) |ω| = 0 for some integer n 0 . We put ω ′ = β n 0 .

In order to prove the second statement, we consider a ¯ d-cocycle α ∈ M M ⊗ p sV and we write α = f (ω) for some ω ∈ M M ⊗ T p (s∧V ). It follows from the definition of f that ∂ω ∈ K (p−1) . Thus, by the first statement, ∂ω = ∂ω ′ some ω ′ ∈ K (≥p) . Then ̟ = ω − ω ′ is ∂-cocycle of K ≥p such that f (̟) = α.
To end the proof, let α ∈ H * [n] (LM ), then by Lemma 6, α is the class of f (β) where β ∈ M M ⊗ T ≥n (s

figure.trash: V ). Therefore Φ(β) ∈ ⊕ i+j≥n M M ⊗ T i (s∧V ) ⊗ M M ⊗ T j (s∧V ) (see Lemma 2). Now since f (M M ⊗ T p (s∧V )) ⊂ M M ⊗ p sV , [Φ(α)] ∈ ⊕ i+j≥n H * [i]
figure.figDesc: (LM ) ⊗ H * [j]

div.p: (LM ) .
Now, as announced in the Introduction (Proposition 3) there is an other interpretation of H n [p]

figure.figDesc: (LM ) in terms of the cohomology of a differential graded Lie algebra. Let L be a differential graded algebra L such that the cochain algebra C * (L) is a Sullivan model of M , [8, p.322]

In particular, the homology of the enveloping universal algebra of L, denoted U L is a Hopf algebra isomorphic to H * (ΩM ). We consider the cochain complex C * (L; U L ∨ a ) of L with coefficients in U L ∨ considered as an L-module for the adjoint representation. We have shown ([12, Lemma 4]
that the natural inclusion C * (L) ֒→ C * (L; U L ∨ a ) is a relative Sullivan model of the fibration p 0 : LM → M . Write C * (L) = ( V, d), then V = (sL) ∨ and ¯ V = L ∨ .

div.p: There is also (Poincaré-Birkoff-Witt Theorem) an isomorphism of graded coalgebras, [8, Proposition 21.2]:

figure.figDesc: γ : L → U L , x 1 ∧ ... ∧ x k → σ∈S k ǫ σ x σ(1) ...x σ(k) .

div.p: If we put Γ p = γ( p V ) we obtain the following isomorphisms of cochain complexes

figure.trash: ( V ⊗ ¯ V , ¯ d) ∼ = C * (L; U L ∨ a ) , G p ∼ = C * (L; (Γ p ) ∨ ) which in turn induce the isomorphisms: IH * (LM ) ∼ = Ext U L (Ik, U L ∨ a ) , IH * [p] (LM ) ∼ = Ext U L (Ik, Γ p (L) ∨ ) . and by duality, IH * (LM ) ∼ = Tor U L (Ik, U L a ) , IH [p]
figure.figDesc: * (LM ) ∼ = Tor U L (Ik, Γ p ) .

analytic.title: Loop Spaces, Characteristic classes and GeometricQuantification

monogr.title: Progress in Math- ematics 107 Birkhä Boston

analytic.title: A model for cyclic homology and algebraic K-theory for 1-connected topological space
String topology, math
